div1.p: Seguin reports on possible yellow fever deaths and public health response in French West Africa.

div1.head: English translation [from French] of letter from [s.n.] Seguin to the Medical Inspector, Director of the Health Service of French West Africa, October 27, 1922
div1.opener:
Seguin L
1 2 & 3 all at Séguo in Sudan
by
Seguin
FRENCH SUDAN
HEALTH SERVICE
Bamako,
October 27, 1922
div1.p:
Séguin, chief physician, 2nd class, and Head of the Health Depart-
ment of the French Sudan, to the Medical Inspector, Director of the Health
Service of French West Africa. Dakar.

I have the honor to inform you that on October 19, immediately on
receiving a telegram from Ségou informing me that Mr. A. of the Niger Mission
was suffering from a serious disease similar to the one that had caused the
death of Mr. B., also of the Niger Mission, three days before, I waited on the
Governor, who had already planned to go to Ségou, and proposed that I accompany
him, in order to carry out on the spot a sanitary investigation that seemed to
me to be demanded by circumtances and to take the steps that the situation
required.

On arriving at Ségou on the morning of the twentieth, I immediately
obtained from Dr. Fortin the following clinical observations: Mr. B. and Mr. A.,
who belonged to the same group of the Niger Mission, had reached Ségou some two
weeks before and both lived at the C.F.A.O., taking their meals with Mr. Rolland,
agent of the C.F.A.O., and with Mr. Collin, a tradesman of Ségou.

On October 12, Mr. B. fell ill with a fever that was very high from
the first, reaching 40.3 degrees and accompanied by the following symptoms:
excitement, red complexion, conjunctiva injected but without ecchymosis, pre-
cordial pain, negative auscultation, bilious vomit. The urine was normal in
quantity and in quality from the beginning to the end, and icterus appeared
at the end of the fourth day. On the morning of the fourth day, October 15,
the patient showed a remission of the symptoms, the temperature fell to 37
degrees, and the patient felt well enough to want to get up and eat.

During this same fourth day the fever returned with agitation and
delirium, and there was a fairly abundant black vomit that adhered to the
sides of the basin and formed a “sémilique”, almost pasty mass that resembled
wet soot.

Ecchymosis appeared on the chest and the abdomen, and there was
anuria during the very last hours, but never any black urine.
Death at 10 o'clock in the morning of October 16.

Treatment: As much as three grams of quinine a day from the first,
for three or four days, by mouth and by injection; subcutaneous injections of
1.30 of Novarsenobenzol; bleeding by scarified leaches followed by injections
of artificial serum (three injections of 350 to 400 C. each) that were rapidly
resorbed and each time brought up the pulse.

Mr. A., who left Ségou on October 16 at 9 o'clock in the morning, one
hour before the death of Mr. B., felt the first symptoms of the disease about
noon.

On coming back to Ségou in the forenoon of the 17th, he was immediately
examined by Dr. Fortin, who found in him the same symptoms as the ones presented
previously by Mr. B., but perhaps even more clearly marked; headache, flushed
face, injected eyes, tongue very white in the middle but with a red line around
the edges, very few bilious vomits, stomach tolerance for liquids, normal urine,
fever of about 40 to 40.5 degrees for three days, lessening of the symptoms at
the end of the third day. Similarly to Mr. B., Mr. A. wanted to get up and eat.

The fever returned on the fourth day, with abundant black hemorrhagic
vomit, ecchymosis under the conjunctiva, abundant, clear but very albuminous urine,
final excitation with delirium, then coma.

The icterus that appeared during the period of remission grew rapidly
worse and reached its greatest intensity after the death on the 19th at 12.30,
noon.

Mr. A., who normally took 1.75 gr. of quinine daily as a preventive,
recieved during the course of the illness large doses of quinine and of 914.

Summing up, Mr. A. and Mr. B., who belonged to the same group and
therefore lived under identical conditions, had been living for two weeks at
the C.F.A.O., when one of them, Mr. B., fell ill on October 12. He died on
October 16 after having revealed the symptoms described above, and on the same
day Mr. A. fell ill with a disease that presented a picture practically iden-
tical with that of Mr. B's.

It is permissible to regret the fact that no blood examination was
made in the case of these two patients when there was at Ségou a microscope and
staining material that I was able to use. Such an examination, seeking to
determine the Obermayer spirochetes or the “hematozosis” would have given
certainty where there is at present only a probability, by bringing to bear
an important diagnostic element. This probability is that Mr. A. and Mr. B.
died from attacks of yellow fever, but it would be imprudent to affirm this
diagnosis with only the clinical information that I received as a basis.

The diagnosis of yellow fever is even more doubtful in the following
cases:

Mr. C., employed by the firm of Maurel and Prom, died on August 16,
at 1 p.m., from the results of attacks of pernicious congestion, according to
the report of Dr. Malaussene, who treated Mr. C. from the beginning of his
illness, that is to say, the forenoon of August 4, without thinking of making
a blood examination that would have made it possible to confirm the diagnosis
of pernicious attacks.

The observations reported by Dr. Malaussene speak of “hémátomès”
and melena, but make no mention of the urine or of icterus.

During these three days of illness there was no fall in temperature
nor remission of the other symptoms, which would render the diagnosis of yellow
-4-
fever much more doubtful in case one ever tried to assimilate Mr. C's case to
those of Mr. A. and Mr. B.

Mr. D., of the Niger Mission, died on September 9 of pernicious coma-
tose attacks.

Mr. E., Postal Receiver, died October 5 of bilious hemoglobinuric
fever, according to the diagnosis of Dr. Fortin, who treated the patient and
gave me the following information as to his case:

High fever of about 40 degrees for 5 days; bilious vomit from the
first; slight icterus from the third day on, but not accentuated after death;
oliguria from the first day; dark red urine; anuria for over 24 hours before
death.

Toward the last the vomit became very dark green, but was never black.
There was no fall in temperature, no injection of the eyes, and no subcutaneous
hemorrhage.

While regretting again that the blood was not examined, some important
differences will be noted between the symptoms of Mr. E. and those of Messrs. A.
and B.

Child F. died on September 13 of gastroenteritis.. Mrs. G., who was
seen on the third day of illness of Dr. Fortin on his arrival in Ségou on Septem-
ber 13, presented symptoms that resembled those of Messrs. A. and B. The fever
was from 38.6 to 39.4 degrees. There was a single scant attack of hemorrhagic
vomit. On the third day there appeared subicterus that got much darker in two
days. The gums bled slightly the whole time. There was ecchymosis on the thighs,
metrorrhagia in the beginning, psychic disturbances and an extraordinary fear of
death.

There was a very short remission during the fifth day of illness, after
which the fever returned, oscillating between 38.6 and 39.4 degrees for about
-5-
twelve days. The quantitatively normal urine was albuminous and had a slight-
ly bilious appearance. The patient had been convalescent for a week when she
was sent to the hospital of Bamako, where she arrived still subfebrile in
the afternoon, with 37.4 to 37.5 degrees of temperature, mental debility and
subicterus.

At present, after (word omitted in original) days of treatment, the
patient is fully convalescent. Her psychic troubles and the icterus have
almost entirely disappeared.

Mrs. G.'s little girl, 5 months old, who was put on a bottle from
the beginning of her mother's illness, is perfectly well and has at no
time revealed any morbid symptoms.

Mr. G., the husband, who was in continual contact with the patient
and who accompanied her to Bamako, was seen by me on his return to Ségou.
He is perfectly well.

In view of these facts, and since it was impossible to make any
affirmative statement, it seemed necessary to isolate the persons who had been
in contact with the patients and to submit them to 10 days' observation, a
long enough period, as the length of the period of incubation of yellow fever
is from 2 to 5 days according to some, and 6 days according to the sanitary
regulations of December 16, 1909.

Therefore the following persons who had been on contact with the
patients were isolated right where they were, in a tent:
1. At Banankoro, Mr. H., of the C.F.A.O., and Mr. I., tradesman.
2. At Sama Markalan, 22 kilometers up the river, on the left bank,
where they were at the time, Mr. J., who had cared for Mr. B. and brought
Mr. A. back to Segou, sick, and Mr. K., who took his meals at the Caron
house during Mr. A.'s illness and had assisted in caring for him.
3. Two kilometers from Ségou, on the Barouéli road, Mr. L., junior,
and Mr. M., who were taking their meals at the Caron house at the time when
-6-
Mr. A. came back there to die. The buildings they occupied were closed and
the mosquitoes in them destroyed by the use of tobacco leaves.

Since then sulphur sticks have been sent from Bamako, and for still
further security a second disinfection will be performed with sulphur fumes
before the suspected buildings are reopened.

Furthermore, isolation rooms hermetically closed with mosquito
nothing have been prepared in the maternity hospital in course of construction,
the only building in Ségou that offered good conditions for the isolation of
patients. After this suspected patients from the cities and from the outside
will be brought there. They would be placed there under double mosquito pro-
tection, and would therefore not be a source of danger for the inhabitants of
Ségou.

These are the measures that have been taken on the very admissible but
not verifiable hypothesis that Mr. B. and Mr. A. died of yellow fever, the origin
of which would however remain unknown. These measures, in addition to a
careful observation of the sanitary condition of the city and its surroundings,
an order prohibiting anyone from going into the native village from sunset to
sunrise, and the organization of mosquito control, although mosquitoes are rare
in Ségou, where I was unable to find any Stegomyia, are of such a nature as to
protect at the same time the health of the community, which is our principal
preoccupation, and the economic condition of the country, concerning which no
one could be indifferent.
